channel.title: Amelio (Czar Reestablishment)
channel.description:
[center][size=24pt][b][u]Amelio: Reestablishing Czar[/u][/b][/size][/center] [center][size=20pt][b][u]Current Version: 1.1[/u][/b][/size][/center]
[size=12pt][b][u][i]Goal:[/i][/u][/b][/size] I'm going to say this once, expecting you to have logically read the first line in this thread: I love czar, and I don't care how unstable and obsolete you think it is. The whole goal of this project is for me to learn the basic core and generics of Runescape Private servers. No matter if it's Czar, Devolution, or something completely different from wL such as Hyperion, they all follow the same format and design. I'm hoping that by sifting through Czar (Allstar) for a long enough time, I'll become accustom to the methods used and learn more efficient ways to process them.
[b][u]Sub-Goal:[/u][/b] I understand there's a large portion of the RSPS scene that still uses Czar like I do. I'm hoping that by making the source more stable, I'll provide a more convenient window for that user-base in order to suit them with the source they prefer. [hr]
[size=12pt][b][u][i]Progress:[/i][/u][/b][/size]
[u][b]Size:[/b][/u] So far I've gotten the whole source down to [b]~2.5Mb[/b]. That's incredibly small compared to [b]Allstar's 10Mb - 12Mb[/b] (forgot the original size; if anyone can post a pic of the original size that would be great).
[center][IMG]http://i40.tinypic.com/qxjk8o.png[/img][/center]
I've also gotten the client class to [b]652Kb[/b]. Once again, that's less than half the size of Allstar's original client class size (around [b]1,400Kb[/b] -- once again a pic with original size would be great). I've also removed 5 useless folders: [font=times new roman][b]connectedfrom, flagged, flaggedauto, logs, and tools[/b][/font]. I either distributed the information to other folders or just completely eliminated their use.
[center][IMG]http://i43.tinypic.com/14lpz55.png[/img][IMG]http://i39.tinypic.com/v3gh0y.png[/img][/center]
[u][b]Optimization:[/b][/u] It's been a while since I've been in the RSPS scene, so just getting back sort of handicaps my capabilities. I haven't done too much other than reduce the number of item classes by merging them into two rather than four. I plan on getting it down to one. There's an incredible number of methods that can be optimized by simply using an array set up. I've also created a new class for commands (though I don't suggest having many commands at all). Other than that, the only thing I've done is merged most of the "moreinfo" save-data into the "character" save-data so that eventually the server will run off of just the character folder. [hr]
[size=12pt][u][i][b]Future and Resources:[/b][/i][/u][/size]
[u][b]Future:[/b][/u] As I've said, I plan on getting this project to the greatest potential Czar has. For next step I plan on rebuilding some skills using arrays rather than the redundant if-statements that Allstar and Czar are so famous for. I also plan on merging all the character save information into one directory rather than having both "moreinfo" and "character".
[u][b]Download:[/b][/u] If you want to download the source and perhaps help contribute to the project the link to the thread containing the current release will be provided below. I don't plan on having a "team" for the project, but a few "hands-on" suggestions could help.
[url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,332861.0.html]Current Amelio Version Thread[/url]

item.title: Amelio (Czar Reestablishment)
item.dc:creator: @dragon39990 dragon39990
item.description:
@dragon39990 wrote:

[quote=“The Soul, post:48, topic:335567”][quote author=dragon39990 link=topic=431947.msg3181806#msg3181806 date=1271375710]
If your talking about Allstar scape by: Mod Allstar its only 2mb
[/quote]

It’s 2mb when it’s compressed; meaning that it’s a lot more when it’s unzipped.[/quote]
Sorry i’ve been away but, you are CORRECT I forgot to unzip it lol it’s ridiculously big!

Read full topic

item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:41, topic:335567”][quote author=The Soul link=topic=431947.msg3175240#msg3175240 date=1270779736]

[quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=431947.msg3175222#msg3175222 date=1270778010]

…

I should also say in doing this your server will be 100% scratch. No I don’t mean scratch as in you wrote it all your self, I mean that Jagex can’t shut it down due to copyright laws on the server code it’s self, due to the fact that the crash patch is also 100% our code and not Jagex’s meaning that we as developers have written all the code now for servers.

We wrote every server’s code, only the client is from Jagex.
[/quote]I’ve heard that the works of the cryption and stream class have been stolen.

You’re right, but everything else was written by us.
[/quote]Well that’s what jmood meant ;).[/quote]

I guess I misread it then. :rolleyes:

Read full topic

item.title: Amelio (Czar Reestablishment)
item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“jmood128, post:36, topic:335567”][quote author=The Reaper X link=topic=431947.msg3174939#msg3174939 date=1270757437]

Here you go, and yes I know that you may have found it.

[code=java]// crash-patched by blakeman8192

/**

  • ISAAC: a fast cryptographic pseudo-random number generator

  • ISAAC (Indirection, Shift, Accumulate, Add, and Count) generates 32-bit random numbers.

  • ISAAC has been designed to be cryptographically secure and is inspired by RC4.

  • Cycles are guaranteed to be at least 240 values long, and they are 28295

  • values long on average.

  • The results are uniformly distributed, unbiased, and unpredictable unless you know the seed.


  • This is the original implementation by Bob Jenkins with some minor changes.


  • Changelog:

  • 050325: Added supplementSeed(int[] seed ) method; made all variables private
  • 050320: Use System.arraycopy() in ISAACAlgorithm(int[] seed)
  • 980224: Translate to Java
  • 970719: Use context, not global variables, for internal state
  • 960327: Creation (addition of randinit, really)

  • @author Bob Jenkins

  • @version 050325
    */
    public class Cryption {
    private static final int SIZEL = 8; // Log of size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int SIZE = 1 << SIZEL; // Size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int MASK = (SIZE - 1) << 2; // For pseudorandom lookup
    private int count; // Count through the results in rsl[]
    private int[] rsl; // The results given to the user
    private int[] mem; // The internal state
    private int a; // Accumulator
    private int b; // The last result
    private int c; // Counter, guarantees cycle is at least 2^40

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance without using a seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx,FALSE) in the C implementation.
      */
      public Cryption() {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      init(false);
      }

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance using a user-provided seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx, TRUE) after putting seed in randctx

    • in the C implementation.

    • @param seed The seed.
      */
      public Cryption(int[] seed) {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      // This is slow and throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if seed.length > rsl.length …
      /*for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; ++i)
      rsl[i] = seed[i]; */
      // … this is faster and safe:
      System.arraycopy(seed, 0, rsl, 0, (seed.length <= rsl.length) ? seed.length : rsl.length);

      init(true);
      }

    /**

    • Generate 256 results.

    • This is a small (not fast) implementation.
      */
      private final void isaac() {
      int i, x, y;

      b += ++c;
      for (i = 0; i < SIZE; ++i) {
      x = mem[i];
      switch (i & 3) {
      case 0:
      a ^= a << 13;
      break;
      case 1:
      a ^= a >>> 6;
      break;
      case 2:
      a ^= a << 2;
      break;
      case 3:
      a ^= a >>> 16;
      break;
      }
      a += mem[(i + SIZE / 2) & (SIZE - 1)];
      mem[i] = y = mem[((x) & MASK) >> 2] + a + b;
      rsl[i] = b = mem[((y >> SIZEL) & MASK) >> 2] + x;
      }
      }

    /**

    • Initialize or reinitialize this instance.
    • @param flag If true then use the seed (which the constructor placed in
    •         <code>rsl[]</code>) for initialization.

    */
    private final void init(boolean flag) {
    int i;
    int a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h;
    a = b = c = d = e = f = g = h = 0x9e3779b9; // The golden ratio

     for (i = 0; i < 4; ++i) {
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 }
 
 for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) { // Fill in mem[] with messy stuff
 	if (flag) {
 		a += rsl[i];
 		b += rsl[i + 1];
 		c += rsl[i + 2];
 		d += rsl[i + 3];
 		e += rsl[i + 4];
 		f += rsl[i + 5];
 		g += rsl[i + 6];
 		h += rsl[i + 7];
 	}
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 	mem[i] = a;
 	mem[i + 1] = b;
 	mem[i + 2] = c;
 	mem[i + 3] = d;
 	mem[i + 4] = e;
 	mem[i + 5] = f;
 	mem[i + 6] = g;
 	mem[i + 7] = h;
 }
 
 if (flag) { // Second pass: makes all of seed affect all of mem[]
 	for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) {
 		a += mem[i];
 		b += mem[i + 1];
 		c += mem[i + 2];
 		d += mem[i + 3];
 		e += mem[i + 4];
 		f += mem[i + 5];
 		g += mem[i + 6];
 		h += mem[i + 7];
 		a ^= b << 11;
 		d += a;
 		b += c;
 		b ^= c >>> 2;
 		e += b;
 		c += d;
 		c ^= d << 8;
 		f += c;
 		d += e;
 		d ^= e >>> 16;
 		g += d;
 		e += f;
 		e ^= f << 10;
 		h += e;
 		f += g;
 		f ^= g >>> 4;
 		a += f;
 		g += h;
 		g ^= h << 8;
 		b += g;
 		h += a;
 		h ^= a >>> 9;
 		c += h;
 		a += b;
 		mem[i] = a;
 		mem[i + 1] = b;
 		mem[i + 2] = c;
 		mem[i + 3] = d;
 		mem[i + 4] = e;
 		mem[i + 5] = f;
 		mem[i + 6] = g;
 		mem[i + 7] = h;
 	}
 }
 
 isaac ();
 count = SIZE;

    }

    /**

    • Get a random integer value.
      */
      public final int getNextKey() {
      if (0 == count–) {
      isaac();
      count = SIZE - 1;
      }

      return (rsl[count]);
      }

    /**

    • Reseeds this random object.
    • The given seed supplements (using bitwise xor), rather than replaces, the existing seed.
    • @param seed An integer array containing the seed.
      */
      public final void supplementSeed(int[] seed) {
      for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; i++)
      mem[i % mem.length] ^= seed[i];
      }
      }
      [/code]
      [/quote]Actually, I wasn’t in the process of searching for it, so thanks for posting it ^-^.

    • That isn’t all you do, if you got to R-S you can get a download of a server containing the crash patch fix to download, I suggest you take the misc, cryption, and stream classes. Ive done the crash patch many times now on Czar bases, you will have a few errors but there nothing no one can fix.

    I should also say in doing this your server will be 100% scratch. No I don’t mean scratch as in you wrote it all your self, I mean that Jagex can’t shut it down due to copyright laws on the server code it’s self, due to the fact that the crash patch is also 100% our code and not Jagex’s meaning that we as developers have written all the code now for servers.[/quote]

    We wrote every server’s code, only the client is from Jagex.

    Read full topic

item.title: Amelio (Czar Reestablishment)
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“The Reaper X, post:35, topic:335567”][quote author=Rixxx link=topic=431947.msg3174630#msg3174630 date=1270730459]
Here you go, and yes I know that you may have found it.

[code=java]// crash-patched by blakeman8192

/**

  • ISAAC: a fast cryptographic pseudo-random number generator

  • ISAAC (Indirection, Shift, Accumulate, Add, and Count) generates 32-bit random numbers.

  • ISAAC has been designed to be cryptographically secure and is inspired by RC4.

  • Cycles are guaranteed to be at least 240 values long, and they are 28295

  • values long on average.

  • The results are uniformly distributed, unbiased, and unpredictable unless you know the seed.


  • This is the original implementation by Bob Jenkins with some minor changes.


  • Changelog:

  • 050325: Added supplementSeed(int[] seed ) method; made all variables private
  • 050320: Use System.arraycopy() in ISAACAlgorithm(int[] seed)
  • 980224: Translate to Java
  • 970719: Use context, not global variables, for internal state
  • 960327: Creation (addition of randinit, really)

  • @author Bob Jenkins

  • @version 050325
    */
    public class Cryption {
    private static final int SIZEL = 8; // Log of size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int SIZE = 1 << SIZEL; // Size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int MASK = (SIZE - 1) << 2; // For pseudorandom lookup
    private int count; // Count through the results in rsl[]
    private int[] rsl; // The results given to the user
    private int[] mem; // The internal state
    private int a; // Accumulator
    private int b; // The last result
    private int c; // Counter, guarantees cycle is at least 2^40

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance without using a seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx,FALSE) in the C implementation.
      */
      public Cryption() {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      init(false);
      }

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance using a user-provided seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx, TRUE) after putting seed in randctx

    • in the C implementation.

    • @param seed The seed.
      */
      public Cryption(int[] seed) {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      // This is slow and throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if seed.length > rsl.length …
      /*for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; ++i)
      rsl[i] = seed[i]; */
      // … this is faster and safe:
      System.arraycopy(seed, 0, rsl, 0, (seed.length <= rsl.length) ? seed.length : rsl.length);

      init(true);
      }

    /**

    • Generate 256 results.

    • This is a small (not fast) implementation.
      */
      private final void isaac() {
      int i, x, y;

      b += ++c;
      for (i = 0; i < SIZE; ++i) {
      x = mem[i];
      switch (i & 3) {
      case 0:
      a ^= a << 13;
      break;
      case 1:
      a ^= a >>> 6;
      break;
      case 2:
      a ^= a << 2;
      break;
      case 3:
      a ^= a >>> 16;
      break;
      }
      a += mem[(i + SIZE / 2) & (SIZE - 1)];
      mem[i] = y = mem[((x) & MASK) >> 2] + a + b;
      rsl[i] = b = mem[((y >> SIZEL) & MASK) >> 2] + x;
      }
      }

    /**

    • Initialize or reinitialize this instance.
    • @param flag If true then use the seed (which the constructor placed in
    •         <code>rsl[]</code>) for initialization.

    */
    private final void init(boolean flag) {
    int i;
    int a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h;
    a = b = c = d = e = f = g = h = 0x9e3779b9; // The golden ratio

     for (i = 0; i < 4; ++i) {
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 }
 
 for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) { // Fill in mem[] with messy stuff
 	if (flag) {
 		a += rsl[i];
 		b += rsl[i + 1];
 		c += rsl[i + 2];
 		d += rsl[i + 3];
 		e += rsl[i + 4];
 		f += rsl[i + 5];
 		g += rsl[i + 6];
 		h += rsl[i + 7];
 	}
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 	mem[i] = a;
 	mem[i + 1] = b;
 	mem[i + 2] = c;
 	mem[i + 3] = d;
 	mem[i + 4] = e;
 	mem[i + 5] = f;
 	mem[i + 6] = g;
 	mem[i + 7] = h;
 }
 
 if (flag) { // Second pass: makes all of seed affect all of mem[]
 	for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) {
 		a += mem[i];
 		b += mem[i + 1];
 		c += mem[i + 2];
 		d += mem[i + 3];
 		e += mem[i + 4];
 		f += mem[i + 5];
 		g += mem[i + 6];
 		h += mem[i + 7];
 		a ^= b << 11;
 		d += a;
 		b += c;
 		b ^= c >>> 2;
 		e += b;
 		c += d;
 		c ^= d << 8;
 		f += c;
 		d += e;
 		d ^= e >>> 16;
 		g += d;
 		e += f;
 		e ^= f << 10;
 		h += e;
 		f += g;
 		f ^= g >>> 4;
 		a += f;
 		g += h;
 		g ^= h << 8;
 		b += g;
 		h += a;
 		h ^= a >>> 9;
 		c += h;
 		a += b;
 		mem[i] = a;
 		mem[i + 1] = b;
 		mem[i + 2] = c;
 		mem[i + 3] = d;
 		mem[i + 4] = e;
 		mem[i + 5] = f;
 		mem[i + 6] = g;
 		mem[i + 7] = h;
 	}
 }
 
 isaac ();
 count = SIZE;

    }

    /**

    • Get a random integer value.
      */
      public final int getNextKey() {
      if (0 == count–) {
      isaac();
      count = SIZE - 1;
      }

      return (rsl[count]);
      }

    /**

    • Reseeds this random object.
    • The given seed supplements (using bitwise xor), rather than replaces, the existing seed.
    • @param seed An integer array containing the seed.
      */
      public final void supplementSeed(int[] seed) {
      for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; i++)
      mem[i % mem.length] ^= seed[i];
      }
      }
      [/code]
      [/quote]Actually, I wasn’t in the process of searching for it, so thanks for posting it ^-^.[/quote]

    • That isn’t all you do, if you got to R-S you can get a download of a server containing the crash patch fix to download, I suggest you take the misc, cryption, and stream classes. Ive done the crash patch many times now on Czar bases, you will have a few errors but there nothing no one can fix.

    I should also say in doing this your server will be 100% scratch. No I don’t mean scratch as in you wrote it all your self, I mean that Jagex can’t shut it down due to copyright laws on the server code it’s self, due to the fact that the crash patch is also 100% our code and not Jagex’s meaning that we as developers have written all the code now for servers.

    Read full topic

item.title: Amelio (Czar Reestablishment)
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“Rixxx, post:34, topic:335567”]Here you go, and yes I know that you may have found it.

[code=java]// crash-patched by blakeman8192

/**

  • ISAAC: a fast cryptographic pseudo-random number generator

  • ISAAC (Indirection, Shift, Accumulate, Add, and Count) generates 32-bit random numbers.

  • ISAAC has been designed to be cryptographically secure and is inspired by RC4.

  • Cycles are guaranteed to be at least 240 values long, and they are 28295

  • values long on average.

  • The results are uniformly distributed, unbiased, and unpredictable unless you know the seed.


  • This is the original implementation by Bob Jenkins with some minor changes.


  • Changelog:

  • 050325: Added supplementSeed(int[] seed ) method; made all variables private
  • 050320: Use System.arraycopy() in ISAACAlgorithm(int[] seed)
  • 980224: Translate to Java
  • 970719: Use context, not global variables, for internal state
  • 960327: Creation (addition of randinit, really)

  • @author Bob Jenkins

  • @version 050325
    */
    public class Cryption {
    private static final int SIZEL = 8; // Log of size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int SIZE = 1 << SIZEL; // Size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int MASK = (SIZE - 1) << 2; // For pseudorandom lookup
    private int count; // Count through the results in rsl[]
    private int[] rsl; // The results given to the user
    private int[] mem; // The internal state
    private int a; // Accumulator
    private int b; // The last result
    private int c; // Counter, guarantees cycle is at least 2^40

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance without using a seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx,FALSE) in the C implementation.
      */
      public Cryption() {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      init(false);
      }

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance using a user-provided seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx, TRUE) after putting seed in randctx

    • in the C implementation.

    • @param seed The seed.
      */
      public Cryption(int[] seed) {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      // This is slow and throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if seed.length > rsl.length …
      /*for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; ++i)
      rsl[i] = seed[i]; */
      // … this is faster and safe:
      System.arraycopy(seed, 0, rsl, 0, (seed.length <= rsl.length) ? seed.length : rsl.length);

      init(true);
      }

    /**

    • Generate 256 results.

    • This is a small (not fast) implementation.
      */
      private final void isaac() {
      int i, x, y;

      b += ++c;
      for (i = 0; i < SIZE; ++i) {
      x = mem[i];
      switch (i & 3) {
      case 0:
      a ^= a << 13;
      break;
      case 1:
      a ^= a >>> 6;
      break;
      case 2:
      a ^= a << 2;
      break;
      case 3:
      a ^= a >>> 16;
      break;
      }
      a += mem[(i + SIZE / 2) & (SIZE - 1)];
      mem[i] = y = mem[((x) & MASK) >> 2] + a + b;
      rsl[i] = b = mem[((y >> SIZEL) & MASK) >> 2] + x;
      }
      }

    /**

    • Initialize or reinitialize this instance.
    • @param flag If true then use the seed (which the constructor placed in
    •         <code>rsl[]</code>) for initialization.

    */
    private final void init(boolean flag) {
    int i;
    int a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h;
    a = b = c = d = e = f = g = h = 0x9e3779b9; // The golden ratio

     for (i = 0; i < 4; ++i) {
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 }
 
 for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) { // Fill in mem[] with messy stuff
 	if (flag) {
 		a += rsl[i];
 		b += rsl[i + 1];
 		c += rsl[i + 2];
 		d += rsl[i + 3];
 		e += rsl[i + 4];
 		f += rsl[i + 5];
 		g += rsl[i + 6];
 		h += rsl[i + 7];
 	}
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 	mem[i] = a;
 	mem[i + 1] = b;
 	mem[i + 2] = c;
 	mem[i + 3] = d;
 	mem[i + 4] = e;
 	mem[i + 5] = f;
 	mem[i + 6] = g;
 	mem[i + 7] = h;
 }
 
 if (flag) { // Second pass: makes all of seed affect all of mem[]
 	for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) {
 		a += mem[i];
 		b += mem[i + 1];
 		c += mem[i + 2];
 		d += mem[i + 3];
 		e += mem[i + 4];
 		f += mem[i + 5];
 		g += mem[i + 6];
 		h += mem[i + 7];
 		a ^= b << 11;
 		d += a;
 		b += c;
 		b ^= c >>> 2;
 		e += b;
 		c += d;
 		c ^= d << 8;
 		f += c;
 		d += e;
 		d ^= e >>> 16;
 		g += d;
 		e += f;
 		e ^= f << 10;
 		h += e;
 		f += g;
 		f ^= g >>> 4;
 		a += f;
 		g += h;
 		g ^= h << 8;
 		b += g;
 		h += a;
 		h ^= a >>> 9;
 		c += h;
 		a += b;
 		mem[i] = a;
 		mem[i + 1] = b;
 		mem[i + 2] = c;
 		mem[i + 3] = d;
 		mem[i + 4] = e;
 		mem[i + 5] = f;
 		mem[i + 6] = g;
 		mem[i + 7] = h;
 	}
 }
 
 isaac ();
 count = SIZE;

    }

    /**

    • Get a random integer value.
      */
      public final int getNextKey() {
      if (0 == count–) {
      isaac();
      count = SIZE - 1;
      }

      return (rsl[count]);
      }

    /**

    • Reseeds this random object.
    • The given seed supplements (using bitwise xor), rather than replaces, the existing seed.
    • @param seed An integer array containing the seed.
      */
      public final void supplementSeed(int[] seed) {
      for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; i++)
      mem[i % mem.length] ^= seed[i];
      }
      }
      [/code][/quote]Actually, I wasn’t in the process of searching for it, so thanks for posting it ^-^.

    • Read full topic

item.title: Amelio (Czar Reestablishment)
item.dc:creator: @Rixxx Rix_
item.description:
@Rixxx wrote:

Here you go, and yes I know that you may have found it.

[code=java]// crash-patched by blakeman8192

/**

  • ISAAC: a fast cryptographic pseudo-random number generator

  • ISAAC (Indirection, Shift, Accumulate, Add, and Count) generates 32-bit random numbers.

  • ISAAC has been designed to be cryptographically secure and is inspired by RC4.

  • Cycles are guaranteed to be at least 240 values long, and they are 28295

  • values long on average.

  • The results are uniformly distributed, unbiased, and unpredictable unless you know the seed.


  • This is the original implementation by Bob Jenkins with some minor changes.


  • Changelog:

  • 050325: Added supplementSeed(int[] seed ) method; made all variables private
  • 050320: Use System.arraycopy() in ISAACAlgorithm(int[] seed)
  • 980224: Translate to Java
  • 970719: Use context, not global variables, for internal state
  • 960327: Creation (addition of randinit, really)

  • @author Bob Jenkins

  • @version 050325
    */
    public class Cryption {
    private static final int SIZEL = 8; // Log of size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int SIZE = 1 << SIZEL; // Size of rsl[] and mem[]
    private static final int MASK = (SIZE - 1) << 2; // For pseudorandom lookup
    private int count; // Count through the results in rsl[]
    private int[] rsl; // The results given to the user
    private int[] mem; // The internal state
    private int a; // Accumulator
    private int b; // The last result
    private int c; // Counter, guarantees cycle is at least 2^40

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance without using a seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx,FALSE) in the C implementation.
      */
      public Cryption() {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      init(false);
      }

    /**

    • This constructor creates and initializes an new instance using a user-provided seed.

    • Equivalent to randinit(ctx, TRUE) after putting seed in randctx

    • in the C implementation.

    • @param seed The seed.
      */
      public Cryption(int[] seed) {
      mem = new int[SIZE];
      rsl = new int[SIZE];

      // This is slow and throws an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException if seed.length > rsl.length …
      /*for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; ++i)
      rsl[i] = seed[i]; */
      // … this is faster and safe:
      System.arraycopy(seed, 0, rsl, 0, (seed.length <= rsl.length) ? seed.length : rsl.length);

      init(true);
      }

    /**

    • Generate 256 results.

    • This is a small (not fast) implementation.
      */
      private final void isaac() {
      int i, x, y;

      b += ++c;
      for (i = 0; i < SIZE; ++i) {
      x = mem[i];
      switch (i & 3) {
      case 0:
      a ^= a << 13;
      break;
      case 1:
      a ^= a >>> 6;
      break;
      case 2:
      a ^= a << 2;
      break;
      case 3:
      a ^= a >>> 16;
      break;
      }
      a += mem[(i + SIZE / 2) & (SIZE - 1)];
      mem[i] = y = mem[((x) & MASK) >> 2] + a + b;
      rsl[i] = b = mem[((y >> SIZEL) & MASK) >> 2] + x;
      }
      }

    /**

    • Initialize or reinitialize this instance.
    • @param flag If true then use the seed (which the constructor placed in
    •         <code>rsl[]</code>) for initialization.

    */
    private final void init(boolean flag) {
    int i;
    int a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h;
    a = b = c = d = e = f = g = h = 0x9e3779b9; // The golden ratio

     for (i = 0; i < 4; ++i) {
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 }
 
 for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) { // Fill in mem[] with messy stuff
 	if (flag) {
 		a += rsl[i];
 		b += rsl[i + 1];
 		c += rsl[i + 2];
 		d += rsl[i + 3];
 		e += rsl[i + 4];
 		f += rsl[i + 5];
 		g += rsl[i + 6];
 		h += rsl[i + 7];
 	}
 	a ^= b << 11;
 	d += a;
 	b += c;
 	b ^= c >>> 2;
 	e += b;
 	c += d;
 	c ^= d << 8;
 	f += c;
 	d += e;
 	d ^= e >>> 16;
 	g += d;
 	e += f;
 	e ^= f << 10;
 	h += e;
 	f += g;
 	f ^= g >>> 4;
 	a += f;
 	g += h;
 	g ^= h << 8;
 	b += g;
 	h += a;
 	h ^= a >>> 9;
 	c += h;
 	a += b;
 	mem[i] = a;
 	mem[i + 1] = b;
 	mem[i + 2] = c;
 	mem[i + 3] = d;
 	mem[i + 4] = e;
 	mem[i + 5] = f;
 	mem[i + 6] = g;
 	mem[i + 7] = h;
 }
 
 if (flag) { // Second pass: makes all of seed affect all of mem[]
 	for (i = 0; i < SIZE; i += 8) {
 		a += mem[i];
 		b += mem[i + 1];
 		c += mem[i + 2];
 		d += mem[i + 3];
 		e += mem[i + 4];
 		f += mem[i + 5];
 		g += mem[i + 6];
 		h += mem[i + 7];
 		a ^= b << 11;
 		d += a;
 		b += c;
 		b ^= c >>> 2;
 		e += b;
 		c += d;
 		c ^= d << 8;
 		f += c;
 		d += e;
 		d ^= e >>> 16;
 		g += d;
 		e += f;
 		e ^= f << 10;
 		h += e;
 		f += g;
 		f ^= g >>> 4;
 		a += f;
 		g += h;
 		g ^= h << 8;
 		b += g;
 		h += a;
 		h ^= a >>> 9;
 		c += h;
 		a += b;
 		mem[i] = a;
 		mem[i + 1] = b;
 		mem[i + 2] = c;
 		mem[i + 3] = d;
 		mem[i + 4] = e;
 		mem[i + 5] = f;
 		mem[i + 6] = g;
 		mem[i + 7] = h;
 	}
 }
 
 isaac ();
 count = SIZE;

    }

    /**

    • Get a random integer value.
      */
      public final int getNextKey() {
      if (0 == count–) {
      isaac();
      count = SIZE - 1;
      }

      return (rsl[count]);
      }

    /**

    • Reseeds this random object.
    • The given seed supplements (using bitwise xor), rather than replaces, the existing seed.
    • @param seed An integer array containing the seed.
      */
      public final void supplementSeed(int[] seed) {
      for (int i = 0; i < seed.length; i++)
      mem[i % mem.length] ^= seed[i];
      }
      }
      [/code]

item.title: Amelio (Czar Reestablishment)
item.dc:creator: @The_Reaper_X The Reaper X
item.description:
@The_Reaper_X wrote:

[quote=“cows1471, post:26, topic:335567”]Fair do’s i didnt think about that.

I hope though sir you will re-write it.[/quote]Most of it I plan on re-writing. I’ve already thought of ways to tackle weapon requirements easily with an arrays. Nearly everything in this source can be made better using arrays. I’ve just yesterday removed thread per client thanks to Graham. I thought about packaging the source completely, but there are a number of users here than wouldn’t be comfortable with that format. I will definitely design a new layout, making new classes for different packets. At the end of this project, I’ll probably release a packaged and an unpackaged.

[quote=“Stupit, post:24, topic:335567”]Reaper how did you get the art behind the icons?
[img]http://i40.tinypic.com/qxjk8o.png[ /img][/quote]I made two layers on Paint.NET. First layer being the text, second layer being the files I cropped.
